3 Introduction | Middle Eastern foresight myths (cid:4)(cid:377)(cid:3)(cid:433)(cid:364)(cid:368)(cid:377)(cid:3)(cid:281)(cid:314)(cid:216)(cid:325)(cid:245)(cid:259)(cid:784)(cid:3)(cid:377)(cid:288)(cid:259)(cid:3)(cid:110)(cid:49)(cid:113)(cid:4)(cid:3)(cid:364)(cid:259)(cid:281)(cid:292)(cid:334)(cid:325)(cid:3)(cid:216)(cid:360)(cid:360)(cid:259)(cid:216)(cid:364)(cid:368)(cid:3)(cid:360)(cid:216)(cid:364) - ticularly unsuited to conducting foresight exer- cises. Its wars, coups and revolutions seemingly come out of the blue, creating a strategic envi- ronment consisting mainly of surprising and disruptive events. It is impossible to envision the future when the present needs to be tended to urgently – or so the reasoning goes. But this reasoning is wrong. To begin with, the concept of events being completely unpredictable (famously known as ‘Black Swans’) does not stand up to scrutiny. Foresight animals But beyond the predictability of events, it is precisely because the region features so many sudden events that foresight is crucial. The constant occurrence of surprises leads to a con- stant reaction to them – the opposite of pro- activity, anticipation and, in the best of cases, policymaking designed to improve things over time. 4 Arab Futures 2.0 | The road to 2030 hijacked by existential events such as wars and revolutions, the solutions to other problems are (cid:360)(cid:334)(cid:368)(cid:377)(cid:360)(cid:334)(cid:325)(cid:259)(cid:251)(cid:795)(cid:3)(cid:216)(cid:314)(cid:314)(cid:3)(cid:405)(cid:288)(cid:292)(cid:314)(cid:259)(cid:3)(cid:377)(cid:288)(cid:259)(cid:3)(cid:325)(cid:259)(cid:410)(cid:377)(cid:3)(cid:245)(cid:364)(cid:292)(cid:368)(cid:292)(cid:368)(cid:3)(cid:292)(cid:368)(cid:3)(cid:363)(cid:384)(cid:292)(cid:259)(cid:377)(cid:314)(cid:411)(cid:3)(cid:292)(cid:325)(cid:3) the making. In that sense, foresight is to decision-making what reconnaissance is to warfare: it provides situational awareness, alerts to challeng- es, shows avenues for possibilities and brings unseen interlinkages to the forefront. If one imagines policymaking to consist of three in- terlooped horizons, most of today’s actions will concern today and tomorrow (‘horizon 1’). But the future does not just consist of tomorrow: it also has medium-term dimensions (anywhere (cid:242)(cid:259)(cid:377)(cid:405)(cid:259)(cid:259)(cid:325)(cid:3)(cid:377)(cid:405)(cid:334)(cid:3)(cid:377)(cid:334)(cid:3)(cid:433)(cid:404)(cid:259)(cid:3)(cid:411)(cid:259)(cid:216)(cid:364)(cid:368)(cid:807)(cid:3)(cid:216)(cid:325)(cid:251)(cid:3)(cid:314)(cid:334)(cid:325)(cid:281)(cid:810)(cid:377)(cid:259)(cid:364)(cid:322)(cid:3)(cid:334)(cid:325)(cid:259)(cid:368)(cid:3) (a decade and longer), what we call ‘horizon 2’ and ‘horizon 3’, respectively. Where policy- making is often busy with horizon 1, foresight is concerned with the latter two. Of course, ef- fective policymaking needs to juggle all three, but most institutions, built for conducting day-to-day business, would collapse if they had to constantly address urgent crises while also imagining a far-away future.
